DOC.HEADLINE: ' THE LOSERS ' IS SILLY, BUT GOOD AT BLOWING STUFF UP

TEXT.P: Like anyone who goes to the movies regularly, I had to make a choice about what to see this week.

Faced with a screening of "The Losers" or "The Back-up Plan" -- Jennifer Lopez's new comedy -- I picked the testosterone-ramped film about double-crossed CIA operatives who join forces with a sinewy mystery woman set on revenge.
The selection may say that I'm drawn by toss-off violence. Because it's certainly not a J.Lo problem. I've liked the hybrid singer-actor-producer for years.

So here I am, left pondering the weird charms of the latest comic-book adaptation come to the big screen. And it comes with a plus: Any film that uses Ram Jam's "Black Betty" and later, Journey's "Don't Stop Believin' " to delirious effect automatically gets love.
Based on a series by Andy Diggle and illustrator Jock, "The Losers" stars Jeffrey Dean Morgan as Clay, or "the Colonel."
His betrayed team is an amiable collection of muscular and lethal gents named Rogue (Idris Elba), Pooch (Columbus Short), Cougar (Oscar Jaenada) and, not so weird, Jenson (Chris Evans).

Zo? Saldana plays Aisha, their dubious associate. For those who don't know what the pretty Saldana looks like from her turn as Neytiri in "Avatar," you will now. There's a lot of the lady here. She arrives tailing Clay around the dives of Bolivia wearing a revealing ensemble and a porkpie hat.
Directed by Sylvain White, "The Losers" is a silly jaunt. Take it too seriously, and it's probably a little specious about U.S. power too.

There is plenty of good-guys-versus-rotten-apple tension here. Before being set up, Clay and company liberate a busload of cute kids and bikini-clad damsels. And make what you will of a character's wearing of an American flag lapel pin, but "The Losers" doesn't require the full force of cultural critique.
The action is a cacophonous mix of emptied ammo clips and clever quips, penned by sometime director Peter Berg and James Vanderbilt.

On the BSU (blow stuff up) meter, it rates an 8. Blast-zone radius and arching missiles get their due, though the bomb the villain hankers for is an environmentally correct weapon of mass destruction.
It's rated PG-13 because violence doesn't rate an R if the sexuality is "sensuality," the cursing's kept to a minimum, and there are explosions, but no in-your-face bloodletting.

There's a smackdown between Clay and Aisha that's sure to evoke memories of Brangelina's throwdown in "Mr. and Mrs. Smith." Grunts, grappling and the Kills' song "U.R.A Fever" lead to a conflagration and an uneasy mission: Get home. Get Max, the mysterious CIA liaison that double- crossed Clay and his men.

Jason Patric's baddie wears impeccably tailored suits and one glove. With that accessory and a sociopath's sly delivery, Max gives off the faint whiff of a Bond villain. It's good to be bad, very bad. And Patric has nasty fun playing dapper and despicable.
"You're not sure how it's going to end, but you're pretty sure it's going to make the papers," says Max to snaky effect.
And he doesn't even have the best lines. Those belong to Evans' character. Consider Jenson the new IT guy -- as in cute information-technology fella.

(info box)
'The Losers' Two and a half out of four stars
PG-13 for sequences of intense action and violence, a scene of sensuality and language.
1 hour, 38 minutes.

Directed by Sylvain White; written by Peter Berg and James Vanderbilt; from the DC comic book series by Andy Diggle and illustrator Jock; photography by Scott Kevan; starring Jeffrey Dean Morgan, Zo? Saldana, Chris Evans, Idris Elba, Columbus Short, Oscar Jaenada, Jason Patric and Holt McCallany.
